title: Seized under proceeds of crime
name: Seized under proceeds of crime
description:
A Map by Vancouverpapers

The Vancouver Sun created this list after examining court files and documents related to the assets seized so far under the province’s Civil Forfeiture Act, which was passed last year. Note: Some of these properties have changed hands.

properties.name: Address of seizure: 4452 256th Street, Langley
properties.description: Posted by Vancouverpapers4452 256th Street, Langley, British ColumbiaAddress of seizure: 4452 256th Street, Langley. Seized asset: ,000 Cdn cash. Reason seized: The money is allegedly related to drug trafficking Named in lawsuit: Bradley Douglas Cook. Synopsis: Police on patrol noticed a Mercury Topaz with three people inside parked on a dimly lit street at night outside Coghlan Elementary school on Dec. 29, 2006. Police checked the vehicle and the driver voluntarily allowed police to check a backpack, which contained one sandwich bag with ,755 in bills and another with ,600, plus ,205 in Cook’s pocket. Also seized were some marijauana and a nine-millimetre round of ammunition. The money was forfeited.

properties.name: Address: 13475 - 57th Ave., Surrey
properties.description: Posted by Vancouverpapers13475 - 57th Ave., Surrey, British ColumbiaAddress: 13475 - 57th Ave., Surrey Seized items: The house and a Commodore 2660 Regal boat. Seized because: Part of the home was used for unlawful activity and the boat was allegedly bought with the proceeds of crime. Named in the lawsuit: David Dennis Peterson. Case synopsis: The home was under police suspicion by late 2002. It wasn’t until 2005 when police busted a marijuana operation in the garage. Police seized 300 pot plants and 46 pounds of “bud” in baggies. Peterson was charged with production of marijuana and pleaded guilty on Feb. 22 last year. He was sentenced to one year in jail. The property was bought for 23,000 in 2001 and now has an assessed value of 20,000. The boat was purchased for 0,000 by refinancing the house mortgage. The case went to court last April when the trial judge, in an interim ruling, allowed the house to be sold for not less than 20,000. The home was sold for 40,000 last June. The court ordered the proceeds to be placed in an interest-bearing trust account pending a final disposition.

properties.name: Address: Various locations in Vancouver, Richmond and Delta.
properties.description: Posted by Vancouverpapers 6480 Woodwards Rd., Richmond, B.C.Address: Various locations in Vancouver, Richmond and Delta. Seized assets: Police executed a search warrant on a safety deposit box and seized the contents, including 82,005 Cdn cash, a diamond ring appraised at 3,800, a Piaget watch purchased for 3,800,two gold chains, a jade pendant and other jewelry. Also seized were 0,000 US cash and another 4,410 in Canadian currency. Reason seized: The police allege the items in the safety deposit box were the “instruments of unlawful activity” and the cash allegedly was related to marijuana-growing operations. Named in the lawsuit: Tsz Wing Ching and Miu Wan (Vivian) Chan. Synopsis: An investigation was conducted by the Combined Forces Special Enforcement Unit. Between May 16, 2002 and March 14, 2003, police executed search warrants at a number of homes leased or owned by Chan, which were found to contain marijuana operations with a plants estimated to be worth .8 million at the street level. In the search at Chan’s home at 6480 Woodwards Rd. in Richmond, police seized 0,000 US from a canvas bag found in the back of a BMW. Another 4,410 Cdn cash was found in her purse. Chan was charged with cultivating marijuana and released on bail. On July 10, 2003 police executed a final search warrant on a safety deposit box jointly held by Ching and Chan, seizing the contents. The Canada Revenue Agency laid claim to 23,881 of the seized money for unpaid taxes and penalties, leaving 3,293 Cdn, plus the jewelry, which was forfeited. According to court documents, before the final seizure, Chan disposed of five and six properties she had bought for almost million between 2001 and 2003. Her current whereabouts are listed as unknown.

properties.name: Asset seized: 00,500 Cdn cash
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersReason seized: Police allege the money is from drug trafficking. Named in lawsuit: Hamed Rahmani. Synopsis: On Oct. 5, 2005, Vancouver police stoped a BMW driven by Rahmani when he was observed, during a police surveillance operation, leaving the residence of a suspected drug dealer. The seized money has been forfeited

properties.name: Seized asset: 2940 Waterford Place, Coquitlam.
properties.description: Posted by Vancouverpapers2940 Waterford Place, Coquitlam, B.C.Seized asset: 2940 Waterford Place, Coquitlam. Reason for seizure: The house was bought with profits from drug-trafficking. Named in lawsuit: Tuan Anh Vu, Phiet Vu and Minh Thi Nguyen. Synopsis: Police were called to the residence on Jan. 11 this year to investigate a home invasion. Officers were met at the door by Anh Vu, who appeared to be wounded. He advised police four or five men dressed in black had entered the residence but he managed to eject them. Police found a marijuana-growing operation in the basement of the home, which was purchased in 2002 for 95,000 by Phiet Vu and Nguyen. Forfeiture proceedings are pending.

properties.name: Seized asset: 3766 Cambridge St., Burnaby, and 26,000 in home furnishings
properties.description: Posted by Vancouverpapers3766 Cambridge St., Burnaby, B.C.Seized asset: 3766 Cambridge St., Burnaby, and 26,000 in home furnishings. Reason for seizure: The home was allegedly purchased with money from drug trafficking. Named in lawsuit: Robert (Robbie) Della Penna, Mario Della Penna, Guiseppe Della Penna, Michela Della Penna. Synopsis of case: Robbie Della Penna, a 37-year-old former boxer, was arrested in October 2004 in a reverse-sting undercover police operation. Police had observed him travelling to a home in Mission, which was a suspected marijuana-growing operation. A police bust on March 5, 2004, found 1,448 live plants and another 1,427 dried plants were seized. Police later used a DEA informant to contact Robbie Della Penna to help broker a 50-kilogram cocaine deal. The accused was arrested as he delivered 75,920 Cdn cash to buy the first 25 kilograms of cocaine. The home was recently sold to new owners for .3 million. About .1 million was forfeited to the government.

properties.name: Seized asset: 3766 Cambridge St., Burnaby, and 26,000 in home furnishings.
properties.description: Posted by Vancouverpapers3766 Cambridge St., Burnaby, B.C.Seized asset: 3766 Cambridge St., Burnaby, and 26,000 in home furnishings. Reason for seizure: The home was allegedly purchased with money from drug trafficking. Named in lawsuit: Robert (Robbie) Della Penna, Mario Della Penna, Guiseppe Della Penna, Michela Della Penna. Synopsis of case: Robbie Della Penna, a 37-year-old former boxer, was arrested in October 2004 in a reverse-sting undercover police operation. Police had observed him travelling to a home in Mission, which was a suspected marijuana-growing operation. A police bust on March 5, 2004, found 1,448 live plants and another 1,427 dried plants were seized. Police later used a DEA informant to contact Robbie Della Penna to help broker a 50-kilogram cocaine deal. The accused was arrested as he delivered 75,920 Cdn cash to buy the first 25 kilograms of cocaine. The home was recently sold to new owners for .3 million. About .1 million was forfeited to the government.

properties.name: Seized asset: 40,820 found in the trunk of a Nissan Maxima, along with two kilograms of cocaine.
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersCambie and West 10th Avenue, Vancouver, B.C.Address of seizure: near Cambie and West 10th Avenue, Vancouver. Seized asset: 40,820 found in the trunk of a Nissan Maxima, along with two kilograms of cocaine. Reason seized: Money allegedly related to drug trafficking. Named in lawsuit: Troy Minh-Tri Tran, Emby Chan Tha Kim and Jesse Alan Reimer. Synopsis: Vancouver police officers on patrol on Oct. 21. 2005, were advised over the police radio about the theft of a Nissan sedan. The car was pulled over on West 10th. The officers found a large amount of cash in the trunk, as well as two plastic-wrapped “bricks” of cocaine. Tran and Reimer were both known to Calgary police. Reimer and Kim failed to file statements of defence, so default judgments were entered against them. Tran consented earlier this year to a forfeiture order. The money was paid to the B.C. minister of finance.

properties.name: Seized asset: 4093 Braefoot, Victoria
properties.description: Posted by Vancouverpapers4093 Braefoot, Victoria, British ColumbiaSeized asset: 4093 Braefoot, Victoria Reason for seizure: Part of the house was bought with funds gained from unlawful activity — fraudulent investment schemes. Named in lawsuit: David Joseph Shannon, Evagelia Biros and John Biros. Synopsis: Shannon was a partner of Kevin J. Steele in a number of investment schemes that constituted fraud. His wife, Evagelia, is a school teacher. Her father John Biros is named because he advanced 00,000 to purchase the 00,000 home by way of a second mortage and remains unpaid. The home was bought in 2004 for 51,000. Steele pleaded guilty to fraud in 2006 and was sentenced to six years in prison after admitting he defrauded more than 200 investors of million. A Chicago court also ordered Steele, 34, who falsely portrayed himself as a hot-shot commodities trader, to pay .4 million US restitution to his victims. In 2006, Shannon transferred his interest in the property to his wife, which is alleged to be a fraudulent conveyance. Shannon and another Victoria man were paid more than 00,000 in commissions for soliciting investors, mainly in New Denver and other towns in the Slocan Valley. Forfeiture proceedings are pending against the home.

properties.name: Seized asset: 4640 Woodburn Rd., West Vancouver
properties.description: Posted by Vancouverpapers4640 Woodburn Rd., West Vancouver, B.C.Seized asset: 4640 Woodburn Rd., West Vancouver. Reason seized: It is alleged that the co-owner of the home, Dale Alexander Prentice, has been directly involved in large-scale trafficking of marijuana and cocaine between Canada and the U.S., and he has been implicated in laundering large sums of money from criminal enterprises. Named in lawsuit: Dale Prentice and Shannon Joanne Bennett. Synopsis: The -million-plus home in Upper Caulfeild was purchased by the defendants in 2005 for 53,000. Prentice was investigated in U.S. by the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), where he was arrested as a large-scale money smuggler. His alleged associates, Andrew Crookbain and Jason Scott Hunter, were accused of conspiracy to import marijuana, conspiracy to distribute cocaine and engaging in money laundering. A supporting affidavit filed by ICE agent Steve Cagen said Hunter was paid ,000 to drive 20,000 US from New York to Los Angeles, then drove to Seattle with 20 kilograms of cocaine. The affidavit says Crookbain is a Canadian detained in Maui last Jan. 29 as a material witness and was escorted to Seattle, where he told police Prentice was growing marijuana in Canada. Prentice entered into a guilty plea agreement with U.S. authorities and was sentenced to a nine-year prison term. Hunter got four years. Crookbain wasn’t charged in the U.S. but faces drug-related charges in Vancouver. Forfeiture proceedings are pending against the West Vancouver home.

properties.name: Seized asset: 6,000 cash found in trunk of a car.
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersVictoria, British ColumbiaSeized asset: 6,000 cash found in trunk of a car. Reason for seizure: Alleged to be proceeds from unlawful activity. Named in lawsuit: Anh Tuan Lam. Synopsis: Victoria police Const. Graeme LeBlanc was on routine traffic patrol on Highway 17 in North Saanich last Feb. 22 when he observed a Nissan Maxima change lanes without making a signal near the BC Ferries terminal. The car was pulled over and the driver, Lam, gave a home address in Victoria, which didn’t exist. The officer ran Lam’s name on the police computer, finding a previous incident where weapons were involved. Lam consented to the officer searching the trunk, where the cash, in 0 bills, was found. Lam stated he was transporting the money for a friend. The cash was forfeited by default after Lam failed to file a statement of defence.

properties.name: Seized asset: 6108/6110 Cedar Creek Rd., Likely, B.C.
properties.description: Posted by Vancouverpapers6110 Cedar Creek Rd., Likely, B.CSeized asset: 6108/6110 Cedar Creek Rd., Likely, B.C. Reason for seizure: Three buildings contained marijuana-growing operations. Named in lawsuit: Wai Kit (Peter) Cheang. Synopsis: Police executed two search warrants on the rural property on Nov. 22, 2006. Police seized 1,971 pot plants from a workshop, 1,094 plants in an A-frame home and 2,501 plants from another building. Two men — Sambath Om and Kim Se Noun — were charged with production of marijuana. Cheang, the property owner since 2005, was not charged. Forfeiture proceedings against the property are pending.

properties.name: Seized asset: 9,780 cash from a vehicle in Clearwater
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersSeized asset: 9,780 cash from a vehicle in Clearwater. Reason seized: The money is alleged to be from drug trafficking. Named in lawsuit: Ron Israel Markowitz of Surrey. Synopsis: Markowitz was stopped in a routine traffic stop and was found to have the cash in his car. The money has been forfeited.

properties.name: Seized asset: House and property
properties.description: Posted by Vancouverpapers29445 Simpson, Rd., Abbotsford, B.C.Address of seizure: 29445 Simpson, Rd., Abbotsford. Seized asset: House and property. Reason seized: The home was allegedly purchased with profits made from a marijuana-growing operation. Named in lawsuit: Ngoc Bich Doan and Chung Kim Diep. Case synopsis: Doan and her husband were arrested Feb. 26, 2003, by Abbotsford police after a search warrant was executed after a tip from BC Hydro. Police seized 235 marijuana plants from the basement. The next year, Doan pleaded guilty to marijuana production and was sentenced to six months of house arrest and fined ,000. Doan stated she and her husband had earned money as labourers and profited from real estate deals before buying their home in Abbotsford. Divorce proceedings were initiated and the house, which was heavily mortaged, was sold in 2006 for 60,000, with Doan and Diep each allowed to keep 8,300. About 29,000 was forfeited to the government.

properties.name: Seized item: ,020 in cash
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersAddress of seizure: Kelowna Seized item: ,020 cash. Seized because: The money is allegedly from drug trafficking. Named in lawsuit: Brandon David Ravell and Courtney Peoples. Synopsis: Kelowna RCMP were patrolling downtown and found an open case of beer in a truck owned by Peoples, which was parked outside a nightclub on April 28, 2007. Forfeiture is pending.

properties.name: Seized item: 00,000
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersSeized item: 00,000. Reason seized: The money was part of a restitution deal worked out with the B.C. Securities Commission to compensate B.C. investors, most of whom were Christian evangelicals, who lost .3 million in an illegal U.S.-based investment scheme. Named in lawsuit: John DeVries, the former leader of the New Life church of Kelowna, who now lives in the Turks and Caicos Islands in the Carribean; and Ernest Reed Grafke, who had been a pastor at the Gateway Church in Southlake, Texas. Case synopsis: DeVries was president and sole shareholder of Amber Enterprises, which encouraged B.C. investors to put .8 million of their money with a U.S. company, which would purportedly buy inexpensive goods in bulk from overseas suppliers and sell them to major retailers such as Home Depot and Costco. Investors were promised returns of 25 to 50 per cent within three to six months, which they could donate to charity. The investment turned out to be a fraudulent Ponzi scheme. The seized money is being distributed to investors who lost money.

properties.name: Seized item: 37,770
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersAddress of seizure: Vancouver International Airport, Richmond. Seized asset: 37,770 cash. Reason seized: The money is allegedly related to drug trafficking. Named in lawsuit: Sol Maya Trickey of Toronto. Case synopsis: Police dog Casey sniffed Trickey’s baggage and detected the scent of illegal drugs on Jan. 29, 2004. The bags were checked and found to contain a significant amount of cash. Trickey also had cash in his pockets. Canada Customs filed a claim for 8,913, leaving 8,857 frozen pending forfeiture.

properties.name: Seized: 00,000 Cdn from a vehicle on Highway 1 in Abbotsford
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersSeized: 00,000 Cdn from a vehicle on Highway 1 in Abbotsford. Reason seized: The money is allegedly from drug production and trafficking. Named in lawsuit: Mark William Wing, the registered owner of a Lincoln Navigator that was stopped while heading westbound on Highway last Jan. 11. The driver was Wing’s brother, Jonathan Mark Wing, and the passenger was Michael James Kiely. It is alleged that all three men are known members of the UN Gang, which is based in Abbotsford. Forfeiture proceedings began Nov. 9.

properties.name: Seized: 06,975 cash in Delta.
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersSeized: 06,975 cash in Delta. Reason seized: The money is allegedly related to drug-trafficking. Named in lawsuit: Jarrod Francis Nicol, who has a criminal record for production of marijuana, possession of drugs for trafficking and currently is in custody at the Fraser Regional Correctional Centre in Maple Ridge. Synopsis: Last May 4, Nicol was driving a Dodge Ram truck pulling a trailer when he was stopped by Delta police. Nicol wasn’t the registered owner of the truck and provided the officer with a copy of his parole release conditions. The officer searched the vehicle and found the cash and a bag containing 65 tablets believed to be the designer-drug ecstacy. Nicol was unable to explain how he obtained the money. Forfeiture is pending.

properties.name: Seized: 1,936 cash, two cellphones, a BlackBerry and car charger.
properties.description: Posted by Vancouverpapers7907-120th St., Delta, British ColumbiaSeized: 1,936 cash, two cellphones, a BlackBerry and car charger. Where: The parking lot of the Cactus Club, 7907-120th St., North Delta. Why: Allegedly instruments of drug trafficking. Accused: Gregory Matthew Allen, who gave his address as 1616 Bayshore Drive, Vancouver. Case synopsis: Delta police noticed a 2006 Ford Explorer and found it was reported stolen. Police observed Allen get in the car. He was arrested and charged with possession of stolen property over ,000. Court documents allege he is involved in drug trafficking and forfeiture is pending.

properties.name: Seized: 1,980 US cash at Douglas border crossing, Surrey
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersSeized: 1,980 US cash at Douglas border crossing, Surrey. Reason for seizure: The source of the money is believed to from unlawful activity. Named in lawsuit: Thanh Phong Le Synopsis: The money was seized at the border on March 27, 1999 from Chi Tung Lau, who said it wasn’t his. Forfeiture proceedings were filed last May against the cash. Le has not relinquished his claim on the money.

properties.name: Seized: 2003 Hummer and 2002 GMC Yukon Denali.
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersSeized: 2003 Hummer and 2002 GMC Yukon Denali. Seized because: the vehicles were allegedly bought with drug-trafficking money and used for drug transactions. Named in lawsuit: David James Endicott and Kathleen Rose Dorward. The vehicles were registered in the name of Dorward, whose occupation is listed as “sex trade worker.” Endicott bragged to Victoria police officers that he was a mid-level drug dealer making about 0,000 a month, using family members to conduct his business. Sgt. Grant Hamilton states he talked to Endicott on Oct. 9, 2005, when Endicott said he was running a drug trafficking business for five years and was making 00,000 a month, paying up to 0,000 to “clean” the money. He told another officer that he and Dorward were selling cocaine and he also ran a paging business. Forfeiture proceedings are pending.

properties.name: Seized: 3,130 US cash and ,240 Cdn cash
properties.description: Posted by Vancouverpapers914 Third St., Nelson, B.C.Seized: 3,130 US cash and ,240 Cdn cash. Where: 914 Third St., Nelson. Why: The money is allegedly related to money laundering, marijuana- growing operations and drug trafficking. Accused: T’ai Me Love Lyon. Case synopsis: Police executed a search warrant at Lyon’s residence on Nov. 2, 2004 as part of a multi-jurisdictional undercover investigation. Police set up a company to provide money laundering services and Lyon allegedly delivered 26,900 to an agent in Denver, Colo., on Sept. 8, 2003, to be laundered. The case has been resolved, with the money forfeited to the government.

properties.name: Seized: 3,500 Cdn. cash
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersSeized: 3,500 Cdn. cash Reason for seizure: The money was alleged being transported from Terrace to Vancouver for drug trafficking. Named in lawsuit: William Robin Dudoward. Synopsis: The money was seized from Dudoward on Aug. 1, 2005, and detained by the civil forfeiture office on Aug. 21, 2006. The money was forfeited to the government after the defendant’s lawyer. Sid Simons, signed a consent order, dismissing the proceedings against the defendant without costs, on Oct. 26, 2006.

properties.name: Seized: 42,505 US seized July 29, 2003 from Van de Nguyen; 80,570 seized Sept. 10, 2003, from Thuy Ngoc Pham.
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersPlace of seizure: Vancouver Seized: 42,505 US seized July 29, 2003 from Van de Nguyen; 80,570 seized Sept. 10, 2003, from Thuy Ngoc Pham. Named in lawsuit: Pham and de Nguyen, who at the time of the seizures were fugitives wanted in Washington State to face money-smuggling charges. Synopsis: The U.S. investigation into cross-border money smuggling involved an undercover agent who infiltrated the alleged smuggling ring that allegedly smuggled .4 million into Canada from the U.S. during a nine-month period ending Sept. 10, 2003. Forfeiture is pending

properties.name: Seized: 5,540 from a vehicle near Greenwood.
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersGreenwood, B.C.Seized: 5,540 from a vehicle near Greenwood. Reason for seizure: The source of the money is alleged to be cocaine trafficking. Named in lawsuit: Sandra Gray of Richmond Synopsis: A rented Dodge Durango was involved in an accident near Greenwood on Oct. 19, 2005, killing the driver of the other car. The driver of the Durango and the passenger, Gray, were taken to hospital for treatment. Found in the back of the vehicle was a black nylon bag containing bundles of cash. Gray initially claimed the money. The driver of the Dodge allegedly told police that Gray had delivered drugs to Grand Forks and was on her way back to Vancouver with the cash. Surrey RCMP Const. Danny Michaud said Reich and Gray were kilogram-level cocaine dealers. Last Sept. 6, 3,000 of the money was released to Gray. Another 0,473 was claimed by the Canada Revenue Agency and the rest was forfeited.

properties.name: Seized: 5300 Willet Rd., Abbotsford
properties.description: Posted by Vancouverpapers5300 Willet Rd., Abbotsford, B.C.Seized: 5300 Willet Rd., Abbotsford. Reason seized: The property is alleged to be the proceeds of crime and an instrument of unlawful activity for growing marijuana. Named in the lawsuit: Maria Stasynec, Paul Michael Stasynec, Tracey Shawn Ruscheinsky, the Royal Bank and Frank Iaci. Synopsis: Maria Stasynec, an esthetician who lived with her husband Paul at 171 Gladwin Rd. in Abbotsford, was the registered owner of the property, which was used for a marijuana-growing operation. Police seized more than three kilograms of pot and charged Ruscheinsky with unlawfully producing marijuana. It is alleged Maria and Paul Stasynec used their profits from the drug trade to buy the Willet Rd. property. The Royal Bank and Frank Iaci, who lives on West 37th in Vancouver, are mortgage “charge holders” on the property’s title and are not accused of being involved in illegal activity. New owners bought the property last May for million, when the mortgages were paid off and the remainder was forfeited.

properties.name: Seized: 7,510 Cdn and 8,855 US cash
properties.description: Posted by Vancouverpapers404 Third St., Nelson, British ColumbiaSeized: 7,510 Cdn and 8,855 US cash. Where: 404 Third Street, Nelson, B.C. Why: The money is allegedly the profits of marijuana-growing and trafficking operations. Accused: Adam Cameron Mintzis. Case synopsis: Police executed a search warrant on Mintzis’ home on Nov. 2, 2004, finding a marijuana-growing operation in the home. Seized at the home was a scribbled note apparently tracking marijuana sales. 3,500 was eventually forfeited and transferred to B.C.’s minister of finance under the Civil Forfeiture Act.

properties.name: Seized: 9,952 US at Pacific border crossing, Surrey
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersSeized: 9,952 US at Pacific border crossing, Surrey. Reason seized: The money is alleged to be the profits of marijuana-growing and trafficking operations. Named in lawsuit: Michael Allen Riley. Synopsis: The cash was seized from Riley on Nov. 26, 1997. He was the passenger in a vehicle entering Canada, which was found to contain a small electronic scale and small amounts of marijuana. Riley is believed to be a U.S. citizen.

properties.name: Seized: Condo at 4132 Halifax St. in Burnaby, 7,000 cash, replica handgun, illegal drugs.
properties.description: Posted by Vancouverpapers4132 Halifax St., Burnaby, British ColumbiaSeized: Condo at 4132 Halifax St. in Burnaby, 7,000 cash, replica handgun, illegal drugs. Why: Allegedly the proceeds or instruments of unlawful activity. Accused: Edison Tse, owner of the condo at the time. Case synopsis: Tse was arrested at the residence along with Genesis Sotana. Both were charged with possession of drugs for the purpose of trafficking. Neither has gone to trial. Status: The condo was sold last summer for 45,000 and the proceeds frozen; the government is seeking forfeiture of the funds.
